article.description:
Michael Olowokandi had every reason to be
distracted Sunday night. If he was, it didn't show.

related.description:
Michael Olowokandi of the Los Angeles
Clippers was booked on three felony allegations after being
arrested Saturday night at his home in Manhattan Beach, Calif.
related.linkText: Clippers' Olowokandi booked on three felony charges
related.title: Olowokandi denies allegations, says truth will come out
related.headline: Olowokandi denies allegations, says truth will come out

article.headline: Olowokandi  has double-double amid felony charges

images.name: McInnis_Jeff 120201 inline
images.caption: The Clippers' Jeff McInnis doesn't even come close to getting this shot past Indiana's Jermaine O'Neal.

article.linkText: Despite arrest, Clippers' Olowokandi  comes through with his best game
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Michael Olowokandi had every reason to be distracted Sunday night. If he was, it didn't show. One day after being arrested on three felony charges, Olowokandi recorded his first double-double of the season with 12 points and 11 rebounds as the Los Angeles Clippers built a 30-point lead through three quarters and beat the Indiana Pacers 103-72 Sunday night. The 7-foot center sat at his locker after the game and spoke briefly about the arrest, but would not take questions. Police released few details other than to say Olowokandi, 26, was arrested about 3:10 a.m. Saturday at his Manhattan Beach home and was booked on allegations of cohabitant abuse, robbery and false imprisonment, all felonies. He was later released on $50,000 bail. "First of all, I'd like to go on record as saying domestic abuse isn't something I make light of," Olowokandi said. "It's something I've never ever participated in. And I think, at the moment, whatever print might be out there might be a little bit out of proportion. And I think, in due time, the truth will come out. "That's a very private matter, and I think out in due time, we will find out that what has indeed been printed or been alleged did not happen. There are numerous witness who were there when this happened, and it is not at all what it seems like," Olowokandi concluded. Olowokandi also blocked five shots. Reserve Quentin Richardson had 21 points for the Clippers, who built a 30-point lead through three quarters and handed Indiana its most lopsided defeat since Isiah Thomas became their coach at the start of last season. "I was definitely fired up," Olowokandi said. "I felt like I did not contribute as much as I would have liked to in Denver, and I saw this game as an opportunity. I knew coach was going to play me a little more tonight, so I didn't want to let him down." Reggie Miller and Austin Croshere each had a team-high 12 points for the Pacers, who lost for the eighth time in 12 games and just the second time in their last 16 meetings with the Clippers. The Clippers' only other victory over Indiana during that span was a 13-point triumph two seasons ago when Miller, who has made more career 3-pointers than any player in NBA history, went 0-for-6 from behind the arc in his first visit to Staples Center. This time, he was 4-for-10 in 23 minutes. "We know what the Clippers are about. They have a lot of weapons when they are rolling," Indiana's Travis Best said. "We just didn't give the effort we needed." The Pacers' collective frustration got to Al Harrington, who picked up two technical fouls from Bob Delaney and was ejected with 33 seconds left in the third quarter with Indiana trailing 79-52. Delaney was the same official who ejected the Lakers' Shaquille O'Neal in the first quarter Friday night at Seattle. The Clippers began the third quarter with a 22-6 run that extended their nine-point halftime lead to 75-48 with 3:42 left in the quarter. Richardson capped the rally with a 3-pointer, one of eight by the Clippers. Richardson led the Clippers to a 53-42 halftime lead with 13 points. Darius Miles added 10 off the bench and also blocked shots by Croshere and Jonathan Bender on the same possession during a 10-4 spurt that opened the second quarter and extended the Clippers' lead to 33-23. Game notes
Clippers guard Eric Piatkowski sat out for the first time this season, bothered by a strained right hip flexor that temporarily kept him from joining Loy Vaught and Randy Smith as the only players in franchise history to play in 500 games. ... Pacers rookie Primoz Brezec didn't play because of a sore right ankle. ... The Pacers concluded their five-game Western trip 2-3. ... The Clippers began a string of eight consecutive games in Staples Center, including a "road" game against the Lakers. ... Jermaine O'Neal, who missed nine of 12 free throws in the victory Saturday at Utah, did not go to the foul line in 31 minutes. ... Jalen Rose, who entered with a team-high 21-point scoring average, has reached the 20-point mark only once in his last nine games. He had eight points in 23 minutes. ... Four of the Clippers' eight victories have come against Eastern Conference teams. Last season, 13 of their 31 victories came against the East.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
